DataElement.preferredName: Lung Tumor Histologic Small Cell Lung Carcinoma Subtype Classification Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the structural pattern of cancer cells used to define a diagnosis related to the histologic classification or category for a highly aggressive subtype of lung carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant small cells and necrosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Lung Tumor Histologic Small Cell Lung Carcinoma Subtype Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the histologic classification or category for a highly aggressive subtype of lung carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant small cells and necrosis histologic classification or category.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredName: Histologic Small Cell Lung Carcinoma Subtype Classification
Property.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:A highly aggressive subtype of lung carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant small cells and necrosis. Metastatic disease is usually present at the time of diagnosis.:A group forming a type within a larger type.:A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.

A highly aggressive carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation arising from the lung. It is characterized by the presence of malignant small cells and necrosis. Metastatic disease is usually present at the time of diagnosis.
A group forming a type within a larger type.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

Supraclavicular; positioned above the clavicle.: On or relating to the opposite side (of the body): A clinical finding indicating that a lymph node is enlarged. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body.
An enlarged lymph node. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Supraclavicular; positioned above the clavicle.: Affecting both sides of the body, or a matched pair of organs.: A clinical finding indicating that a lymph node is enlarged. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
An enlarged lymph node. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to abnormal cell activity manifested by decreased control over growth and function, causing tumor growth or spread into surrounding tissue and adverse effects to the host.: Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

Concepts.definition: Refers to abnormal cell activity manifested by decreased control over growth and function, causing tumor growth or spread into surrounding tissue and adverse effects to the host.

Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (thor-ASS-ik) Having to do with the chest.: Happening or arising or located outside or beyond some limits, or especially, some surface.: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Concepts.definition: Having to do with the chest.
Happening or arising or located outside or beyond some limits, or especially, some surface.
A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.
